name: Coimbatore
fun_fact: Fun fact: Coimbatore is the heart of Kongu Nadu cuisine, a distinct Tamil culinary tradition that uses gingelly (sesame) oil generously, fresh turmeric, and conservative spices compared to its famous cousin Chettinad cuisine. The region is Tamil Nadu's highest producer of turmeric, gingelly, and coconuts, which directly shapes the rustic, ingredient-forward cooking style.

hero_dishes.name: Pallipalayam Chicken
hero_dishes.description: Succulent pan-fried chicken nuggets with copious shallots, dried red chilies, and fresh coconut bits - minimal spices, maximum flavor
hero_dishes.origin_story: Named after Pallipalayam, a quaint town on the Cauvery River bank in Namakkal district. This signature Kongu Nadu dish became synonymous with the town's name. The rustic preparation uses simple ingredients but delivers wonderful peculiar flavors - shallots and red chilies are still the primary ingredients after decades.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Junior Kuppanna (serving since 1960, preserving Kongu Nadu legacy); Valarmathi Mess (Racecourse area, family-run cafÃ©-style, coconut slivers garnish); featured at 2024 Chennai Food Festival as 'Namakkal Pallipalayam Chicken'

hero_dishes.name: Mutton Chukka
hero_dishes.description: Spicy, flavorful dry mutton preparation - a Kongu Nadu specialty with simple spices and coconut paste finish
hero_dishes.origin_story: Kongu people love simple meals with two or three meat dishes, and mutton chukka is at the top. The Kongu way doesn't use a large number of spices - it's rustic cooking that finishes with coconut paste, letting the meat shine.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Junior Kuppanna (legendary eatery, famous mutton chops and chukka); Kongu Unavagam (mouth-watering mutton chukka alongside pepper chicken); Hotel Junior Kuppanna (multiple locations)

hero_dishes.name: Authentic South Indian Breakfast
hero_dishes.description: Fluffy idlis, crispy vadas, various dosas and uttapams served with chutneys and podis (spice powders)
hero_dishes.origin_story: Coimbatore's breakfast culture centers on perfectly steamed idlis unlike anywhere else. The traditional methods have remained unchanged for decades at places like Sree Annapoorna, serving locals since the chain began.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Murugan Idli Shop (soft idlis in various types with chutneys and podis, properly steamed); Shree Annapoorna (100 Feet Road, Tatabad - oldest chain, known for taste for decades); Sree Annapoorna Sree Gowrishankar

hero_dishes.name: Kongu Nadu Traditional Pot Cook
hero_dishes.description: Meals cooked in traditional clay pots over wood fire, preserving ancient cooking methods
hero_dishes.origin_story: Kongu Nadu cuisine has remained simple and unchanged over centuries, shaped by agricultural practices and trade routes. Pot cooking represents this unbroken tradition of rustic preparation.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Ammayi Veedu Pot Cook - original authentic taste, loads of food in good quantities, different style focusing on traditional cooking modes

signature_drinks.name: Filter Coffee (Kaapi)
signature_drinks.description: Strong South Indian coffee brewed in traditional metal filters, mixed with frothy milk
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Morning ritual at restaurants and messes, served in steel tumblers and davaras (saucers), cooled by pouring between vessels. Locals have specific preferences for 'degree' (milk ratio).

signature_drinks.name: Fresh Buttermilk (Mor/Neer Mor)
signature_drinks.description: Spiced yogurt-based drink with curry leaves, green chilies, and ginger
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Essential accompaniment to spicy meals, especially after mutton chukka or Pallipalayam chicken. Cooling effect balances the heat.
